List-

Can Peter Bleed contact me at this email address.
There seems to be some sort of problem with his email.

Email messages to him have bounced, and an attempt to
reply to a message of his from the above '.edu'
address seems to have bounced as well.

Curran
neobliviscar@...







--- Peter A Bleed <pbleed1@...> wrote:
> 
> 
> 
> 
> Peter,
> Interesting.  In the intro to the missing kokuho
> section list in the YNL,
> Yamanaka mentions contributing to a magazine article
> on the subject by Alan
> Schwartz.  He doesn't mention the name of the
> magazine the article was
> published in... for reasons that are now obvious
> assuming that this is the
> same article.  The date would be a rough match.
> 
> Jim
> 
> 
> 
> Jim and All,
> I got the magazine out last night and think it is
> interesting enough in the
> history of sword collecting to recall to other. The
> article appears in the
> SAGA, 1965, I think the August issue. The 'article'
> is really very short
> and full of total hooey. Yamanaka is mentioned as
> the authority but not the
> author. There are about a dozen nicely mounted
> swords shown
> non-technically. These are noted as from the Ussui
> collection, but not
> described at all. Then there is the list of 14 lost
> treasures. Each of
> these gets a couple of paragraphs that list maker,
> date of recognition, and
> date/place of surrender and in most cases the name
> of the American soldier
> who received it. The source of this information is
> not explained.
> My recollection is that the list that Albert
> presented in the Newsletter
> was longer, but much less detailed in that it did
> not contain all the other
> background information. I have never seen this list
> presented anywhere
> else.
> Peter
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
>
